Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Neuromuscular Blocking Agents in Anesthesia

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from diverse age groups, with eligibility criteria including age-specific physiological characteristics. The study was conducted in a clinical anesthesiology setting.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved administering NMBAs with adjustments based on age-related pharmacokinetics, compared to standard dosing regimens.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to clarify dosage differences and their physiological bases.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of residual muscle blockade, measured over a 24-hour period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in residual blockade (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects being the most common.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the Anesthesiology Research Foundation.
